Posted By: audiojunki (11/29/2012 9:37:22 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
For casual, love him alongside Soul Foundry. If you imprint him on it, he and his token buddies are making themselves bigger, and if they make contact they're making extra copies of themselves. If you imprint something even better on the Foundry - say, an Acidic Slime or Primeval Titan or something - he'll make extra copies of those lovelies, rather than just making extra 1/1 Saprolings or whatnot.  
  
Throw in the fact that he's part green - meaning that you can run Dryad Arbor in the same deck - and even if you're just playing him naturally he can easily be above curve on the turn he comes out.
posts.html:
For casual, love him alongside Soul Foundry. If you imprint him on it, he and his token buddies are making themselves bigger, and if they make contact they're making extra copies of themselves. If you imprint something even better on the Foundry - say, an Acidic Slime or Primeval Titan or something - he'll make extra copies of those lovelies, rather than just making extra 1/1 Saprolings or whatnot.

Throw in the fact that he's part green - meaning that you can run Dryad Arbor in the same deck - and even if you're just playing him naturally he can easily be above curve on the turn he comes out.

Posted By: wholelottalove (10/13/2012 7:38:31 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Eh... he's okay. Everyone's gushing over the fact that he only costs three, but that's also his greatest weakness.  
  
Condition 1: you cast him on turn three, and probably don't have enough creatures to discourage your opponent just blocking and killing it on turn four. Not to mention you probably don't have all that many tokens out yet anyway.  
  
Condition 2: you cast him late game, and WHOA! This guy's massive! You have tons of creatures! ...but so do they. \*chump block\*.  
  
Of course, this card is infinitely better with trample, but isn't everything anyway? 3/5
posts.html:
Eh... he's okay. Everyone's gushing over the fact that he only costs three, but that's also his greatest weakness.

Condition 1: you cast him on turn three, and probably don't have enough creatures to discourage your opponent just blocking and killing it on turn four. Not to mention you probably don't have all that many tokens out yet anyway.

Condition 2: you cast him late game, and WHOA! This guy's massive! You have tons of creatures! ...but so do they. *chump block*.

Of course, this card is infinitely better with trample, but isn't everything anyway? 3/5
